title: Zero E field of 2 point charges

content.question: Two stationary point charges <math alttext="negative Q sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>âˆ’</mo><msub><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="positive Q sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> are separated by a distance <math alttext="d" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> as shown above. If the distance from <math alttext="positive Q sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> to point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="one fourth d" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, what must be the relationship between the magnitudes of the charges for the electric field to be zero at point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

unit.text: 8: Electric Charges, Fields, and Gauss's Law

skill.text: 2.A: Derive a symbolic expression from known quantities by selecting and following a logical mathematical pathway.
